legal_regulatory.title: Legal and Regulatory
findings: LEGAL AND REGULATORY This section will examine the legal and regulatory aspects of Artificial Intelligence.
Key components of this framework include laws on AI governance, data protection and privacy, data sharing and accessibility, and freedom of information, among others.
For AI, this pertains to the AI Act, Digital Services Act, Digital Market Act and Data Act, while the older privacy legislation of the EU (GDPR) is highly relevant as well.
AI POLICY AN D REGULATION AI POLICY AND REGULATION Strategic Action Plan for Artificial Intelligence (SAPAI) In 2019, the Strategic Action Plan for Artificial Intelligence was published.
This plan describes the government's intentions to accelerate the development of AI in the Netherlands and to profile the Dutch activities internationally.

Track 1 focuses on capitalizing on societal and economic opportunities, highlighting AI’s ability to address societal challenges, enhance government efficiency in public tasks, and stimulate AI entrepreneurship.
The country offers excellent training for living with AI and developing talent for AI-related work.
Furthermore, the Netherlands enhances AI development through abundant usable data and boasts superior digital and intelligent connectivity.
strengths: Establishing a robust regulatory framework is essential for ensuring the ethical use of AI systems.
Track 2 emphasises creating the right conditions, with the Netherlands leading in high-quality AI research and innovation in Europe.

Track 3 aims at strengthening foundations by ensuring the protection of public values and human rights, fostering trust in AI, maintaining open and competitive markets with robust consumer protection, and safeguarding the safety of citizens, businesses, and government entities.

social_cultural.title: Social and Cultural
findings: SOCIAL AND CULTURAL DIVERSITY, INCLUSION AN D EQUTY DIVERSITY, INCLUSION AND EQUALITY This section explores the social and cultural dimensions, which are essential for evaluating ethical aspects of AI system deployment.
These dimensions focus on preventing biases throughout the AI lifecycle and fostering a fair, inclusive AI ecosystem.

Key topics covered include the participation of women in science, technology, engineering, mathematics (STEM), and AI development, along with the integration of social and cultural diversity to promote ethical AI use.

Furthermore, this section examines public attitudes and trust in AI, and the emphasis on health, social well-being, and cultural considerations in AI solutions such as the use of AI for preserving cultural heritage.

Outside the scope of the suggested RAM indicators, we have also considered Dutch policies related to AI and the media in line with policy area 9 communication and information in the 2021 Recommendation on the ethics of AI.
The most recent Dutch policy document concerning gender and LGBTIQ+ equality policy is the Gender and LGBTIQ+ Equality Policy Plan 2022-2025.

scientific_educational.title: Scientific and Educational
findings: Since these components play a vital role in advancing AI, assessing them provides valuable insight into a country’s AI readiness.

The scientific dimension is evaluated through the nation’s research and innovation (R&I) performance, which includes metrics like R&D spending, research output, ethical AI research, and innovation in AI talent.
On the other hand, the educational dimension is measured by factors such as educational strategies, infrastructure, curriculum quality, attainment levels, and public accessibility to AI education.
The impact of AI on science and research and related policies has become relatively recently a topic of international policy interest124.

Within UNESCO, the opportunities and challenges at the intersection of open science and AI have recently been debated.125 The European Commission and its Member States including the Netherlands have become active in studying the impact of AI on research and innovation and developing a policy agenda
Firstly, accelerating the adoption of AI by scientists, by creating essential enablers such as improved access to data, computational power, and talent.

In the context of the ERA policy agenda 2025-2027, the European Commission, EU Member States and stakeholders have jointly developed in March 2024 a set of guidelines to support the European research community in their responsible use of generative AI.130 These living guidelines provide simple and a
The Dutch Research Council (NWO) has recently set itself guidelines regarding the use of generative artificial intelligence (GAI) for 124 See OECD.
strengths: Additionally, the European Research Council (ERC) grants support to investigation-driven frontier research across all fields based on scientific excellence, including top leading AI research.
Regarding more advanced technologies, such as AI- powered tools, the EU AI Act aims to tackle their increasing use in education.

findings: Economic Affairs (EZ), the Minister of Digitalisation (BZK), and the Minister of Justice and Security (JenV) are jointly responsible for the government-wide national AI policy including preparing negotiations for the Netherlands’ contribution to European or international AI regulations.
Other ministries provide input on AI related issues when these relate to their specific policy areas.
The Ministry of OCW, whose own competences include culture, media, education and science policies, is also the coordinating ministry regarding emancipation policy.

The Minister of Foreign Affairs (BZ) has an overall responsibility for the coordination of the Dutch positions in the European Union and global fora such as the United Nations, and is responsible for Dutch contributions and diplomacy with regard to global AI governance, AI in the military domain, an

technological_infrastructural.title: Technological and Infrastructural
findings: TECHNICAL AND INFRASTRUCTURAL INFRASTRUCTURE AN D CONNECTIVITY INFRASTRUCTURE AND CONNECTIVITY This section will address the infrastructural and technical dimensions of AI.
These dimensions pertain to a country's capacity for developing and deploying AI solutions, including computing power, data centre availability, connectivity, and internet access.
Such elements are critical enablers for AI development, as they shape a country's ability to process information and support the necessary infrastructure for AI systems.

Figure 0.11: Infrastructure and access (per 100 inhabitants, 2022).181 Based on ITU data from 2022, the Netherlands has 118 mobile telephone subscriptions per 100 inhabitants, as well as 123 active mobile broadband subscriptions.
The Amsterdam Internet Exchange (AMS-IX),191 one of the world's largest data transport hubs, further enhances the Netherlands’ appeal for data centre operations.
The Netherlands is home to 81 data centres.

strengths: The Netherlands excels in digital connectivity, with widespread high-speed internet access and a robust telecommunications infrastructure, making it a leader in technology adoption and innovation.

The leading position that the Netherlands has had for a long time is now under pressure, as observed for example by SURF and the Dutch Sea Cable coalition.190 Data centres Data centres in the Netherlands are a critical component of the country's digital infrastructure, contributing significantly to
Strategically located within Europe, the Netherlands offers excellent connectivity to major markets, supported by a robust and extensive fibre-optic network.
The country is home to numerous data centres, including hyperscale facilities operated by leading tech companies such as Microsoft, Google, and Amazon.

Additionally, the Dutch government and private sector are committed to sustainable practices, with many data centres utilizing green energy sources and innovative cooling technologies to minimize environmental impact.
On 24 January 2024, the European Commission launched the AI Innovation Package, which included the concept of an AI factory194.

This achievement is largely due to the country's well-established and dynamic research and innovation ecosystem around AI as government, private companies, and higher-education institutions collaborate effectively.
The Netherlands is well aligned with the UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of AI as it established a supervising authority.

In summary, the Netherlands’ robust performance across all the dimensions can be attributed to the synergistic relationships developed over years of collaboration between government, industry, and educational institutions.

recommendations.title: Clearly delineate how to address the use of AI under the exclusions of the AI Act and take a leadership
recommendations.text: Clearly delineate how to address the use of AI under the exclusions of the AI Act and take a leadership position on the topic of human rights

recommendations.title: Under the AI Act, several sectoral exclusions are stipulated (defence and military, national security, scientific research
recommendations.text: Under the AI Act, several sectoral exclusions are stipulated (defence and military, national security, scientific research and development). Some sectors come with specific provisions (law enforcement, public security, and open-source development). The exclusions are, for example, for national security, “justified both by the fact that national security remains the sole responsibility of Member States in accordance with Article 4(2) TEU and by the specific nature and operational needs of national security activities and specific national rules applicable to those activities” (AI Act, 2024,

recommendations.title: Article 24). It is worthy to note that the exclusion does not apply to dual-use technologies (i.e. those also used outside
recommendations.text: Article 24). It is worthy to note that the exclusion does not apply to dual-use technologies (i.e. those also used outside of the national security context) and that there is no clear definition of national security provided. The exclusions were debated extensively, both during the negotiation phase of the AI Act and by human rights groups.210 The Netherlands’ Stakeholder Team also highlighted caveats and potential weaknesses caused by the exclusions. Stakeholders mentioned the lack of clarity on the scope of national security, the potentially blurry lines between national and public security, and the high-stakes at hand which need to be assessed on a case-by-case basis to meet the requirements of the European Charter of Fundamental Rights.211 The stakeholders argued that the Netherlands must clearly delineate how to address the use of AI under the exclusions of the AI Act and take a leadership position on the topic of human rights. Government response The Dutch government acknowledges the exception in the European AI Act for among others national security, military or defence purposes. However, the Dutch government emphasises the need for the responsible and lawful use of AI. 210 Refer to the joint analysis of leading digital, human rights and social justice groups entitled EU’s AI Act fails to set gold standard for human rights (2024). Amongst others, contributors include representatives from Amnesty International, Algorithm Watch, and Bits of Freedom 211 Powell, R. (2024). The EU AI Act: National Security Implications (Centre for Emerging Technology and Security: Explainer). The Alan Turing

recommendations.title: Institute. https://cetas.turing.ac.uk/publications/eu-ai-act-national-security-implications
recommendations.text: Institute. https://cetas.turing.ac.uk/publications/eu-ai-act-national-security-implications 72 This means that use of AI for national security, defence or military purposes should also comply with existing rules and legislation, and notes that dual use technologies fall within the scope of the AI Act. The Dutch Intelligence and Security Services Act 2017 (Wet op de inlichtingen- en veiligheidsdiensten (Wiv) 2017) governs the lawful use of automated data-analysis, which includes algorithms and AI, by the Dutch General Intelligence and Security Service (Algemene Inlichtingen en Veiligheidsdienst, AIVD). The Wiv 2017 contains an explicit legal prohibition on promoting or taking measures against a person solely on the basis of results of automated data analysis. In all cases, there will be a human assessment. Furthermore, the law states that the processing of personal data solely on the grounds of a person's religion or belief, race, trade union membership, health and sexual life is not permitted. The Oversight Committee for the Intelligence and Security Services (Commissie van Toezicht op de Inlichtingen- en

recommendations.title: Veiligheidsdiensten, CTIVD) (retroactively) monitors the compliancy of the AIVD with the Wiv 2017. This includes
recommendations.text: Veiligheidsdiensten, CTIVD) (retroactively) monitors the compliancy of the AIVD with the Wiv 2017. This includes activities with the use of algorithms and AI. To address the issue of artificial intelligence in autonomous weapon systems, the Netherlands actively engages in the

recommendations.title: Group of Governmental Experts on Lethal Autonomous Weapon Systems (GGE LAWS) of the United Nations Office
recommendations.text: Group of Governmental Experts on Lethal Autonomous Weapon Systems (GGE LAWS) of the United Nations Office for Disarmament Affairs (UNODA) as well as other pertinent international fora and conferences. During the period of 2024–2026, the Dutch disarmament ambassador serves as Chair of the GGE LAWS. A central topic of discussion within the GGE LAWS is the application of international law, particularly international humanitarian law. The Netherlands often emphasizes the significance of international human rights law as a relevant legal framework for the potential development, deployment and use of weapon systems with autonomous capabilities and advocates for the inclusion of this topic in international discussions. Notably, the human rights legal framework imposes more stringent requirements on the use of deadly force in law enforcement contexts compared to the provisions of international humanitarian law governing combat operations. In 2023, the Netherlands’ government published a 2023-2027 strategy on data science and AI for defence.212 This

recommendations.title: Strategy prioritises investments in knowledge building in relation to ethical issues and meaningful human control, and
recommendations.text: Strategy prioritises investments in knowledge building in relation to ethical issues and meaningful human control, and aims to improve regulation and supervision on the use of algorithms within ethical and legal frameworks. In the context of AI for military purposes this is realised by adhering to NATO’s Principles of Responsible Use, as stipulated in the (revised) NATO AI Strategy213, the main principle in this context begin lawfulness (“AI applications will be developed and used in accordance with national and international law, including international humanitarian law and human rights law, as applicable”). In addition, to address the application of AI for defence and military purposes, the Netherlands has taken up an international leadership role by initiating the international discussion on responsible AI in the military domain. In 2023, the Netherlands hosted the Responsible AI in the Military domain (REAIM) Summit.214 As part of the summit’s outcomes, a Global Commission on Responsible AI in the Military Domain was launched by the Netherlands. In 2024, the

recommendations.title: Netherlands co-hosted the second REAIM Summit hosted by the Republic of Korea. The REAIM Blueprint for Action
recommendations.text: Netherlands co-hosted the second REAIM Summit hosted by the Republic of Korea. The REAIM Blueprint for Action affirmed the importance of international human rights law for the development, deployment and use of AI in the military domain.215

recommendations.title: Following a joint Call to Action that government representatives issued at REAIM 2023 in the Netherlands, in 2024 the
recommendations.text: Following a joint Call to Action that government representatives issued at REAIM 2023 in the Netherlands, in 2024 the Netherlands and the Republic of Korea tabled the United Nations Resolution on AI in the military domain and its 212 Defensie Strategie Data Science en AI 2023-2027 | Rapport | Rijksoverheid.nl 213 https://www.nato.int/docu/review/articles/2021/10/25/an-artificial-intelligence-strategy-for-nato/index.html. 214 https://voorlichting.rijksoverheid.nl/ministeries/ministerie-van-buitenlandse-zaken/evenementen/reaim 215 REAIM. 73 implications for international peace and security, that was supported by a very large majority of States in the UN

recommendations.title: General Assembly.216 By endorsing this resolution States affirmed that international law, including the Charter of the
recommendations.text: General Assembly.216 By endorsing this resolution States affirmed that international law, including the Charter of the United Nations, international humanitarian law and international human rights law, applies to matters governed by it that occur throughout the life cycle. The purpose of the UN resolution is to ensure that this issue is discussed more often and in greater detail by all the countries in the world. In the coming years, the Netherlands will continue to play a leading role in advancing the international debate on responsible application of AI in the military domain.

recommendations.title: Consider sovereignty on all layers of the technology stack in order to develop targeted efforts that
recommendations.text: Consider sovereignty on all layers of the technology stack in order to develop targeted efforts that increase competitiveness and reduce dependencies In spite of significant regulatory efforts and governance initiatives on AI, the Netherlands’ Stakeholder Group suggested that efforts should take into consideration all layers of the technology stack model (Figure 0.1) in order to have an overarching approach to digital open strategic autonomy.217 Digital sovereignty leads to agency in deciding the norms and values that AI tools should abide by. While the impact of AI is currently addressed on an infrastructural and technological level, more attention should go towards the application layer upon which digital platforms operate. In many different sectors such as education, digital platforms of Big Tech companies are pushing out smaller players in the national market, leading to dependencies and vendor lock-ins, privacy issues and market deterioration.

recommendations.title: Figure 0.1: (Simplified) technology stack model (adapted from Stolwijk et al., 2024).
recommendations.text: Figure 0.1: (Simplified) technology stack model (adapted from Stolwijk et al., 2024). The ambiguity of regulating digital technologies has to do with their complexity and diversity. They involve multiple ingredients – data centres and graphic cards, networks and connectivity, data, and applications, and much more. In that context, it is worthwhile to consider complexity by means of a layered model.218 Once split into layers, it is possible 216 https://www.government.nl/latest/news/2023/02/16/reaim-2023-call-to-action 217 Stolwijk, C., Punter, M., Timmers, P., Rabbie, J., Regeczi, D., & Dalmolen, S. (2024). Towards a sovereign digital future – the Netherlands in Europe. TNO. 218 Sheikh, H. (2022). European Digital Sovereignty: A Layered Approach. Digital Society, 1(3), 25. https://doi.org/10.1007/s44206-022-00025- z User interfaces Applications Intelligence Data Soft and hard infrastructures Data sharing infrastructures Cloud and edge infrastructures Networks and connctivity (Micro)chips Resources 74 to identify dependencies and disentangle complexity from different perspectives.219 When focusing on (artificial) intelligence – one of the layers –, there are strong interlinkages to other layers such as chips, processing units, or cloud. The main conclusion to be drawn from this exercise for policy and regulation is that while national and European strategies to increase sovereignty and open autonomy show momentum, the scale in both ambition and financial terms is far below that of Chinese and American strategies. Hence, the recommendation of the Netherlands’

recommendations.title: Stakeholder Team is first to consider sovereignty on all of the layers and second, to develop targeted regulatory efforts
recommendations.text: Stakeholder Team is first to consider sovereignty on all of the layers and second, to develop targeted regulatory efforts and policy initiatives that increase competitiveness and reduce dependencies. Government response

recommendations.title: Digital sovereignty is an important topic for the Dutch government. In 2023, the Agenda on Digital Open Strategic
recommendations.text: Digital sovereignty is an important topic for the Dutch government. In 2023, the Agenda on Digital Open Strategic Autonomy (DOSA) was published.220 This agenda recognizes the increasing dependency on third countries for our digital technologies. The agenda has six stack levels: resources, hardware, physical infrastructure, soft infrastructure, data, and applications and services. On the basis of these stack levels, the agenda identifies several specific policy priorities: critical raw materials, quantum technology, photonics, semiconductors, network technology, open-source software, cloud, AI, cybersecurity, and office software. It also identifies more general priorities, such as competitiveness, effective policy and decision making, security policy, knowledge and skills, and international cooperation. With each priority, current and new (policy) initiatives are announced on the national and the EU level. In general, the Netherlands tries to keep digital sovereignty and open strategic autonomy on the EU-agenda, which is in line with the portfolio of the new EU Commissioner on Tech Sovereignty, Security and Democracy in 2024-2029, Ms. Henna Virkkunen. In the education sector, specific attention is directed at the implications of the EU Data Act and the Digital Services Act among others, on primary education and the digital applications used in it. The application of the General Data

recommendations.title: Protection Regulation (AVG) has already shown that EU regulation is an effective instrument to safeguard public values
recommendations.text: Protection Regulation (AVG) has already shown that EU regulation is an effective instrument to safeguard public values in education.221 The Dutch government has also recently mandated a study on alternatives for big tech platforms in education with a strong focus on public values such as privacy.222 The new Dutch Digitalisation Strategy (NDS) to be published in 2025 will continue to build on the work on safeguarding public values by the previous cabinet.223

recommendations.title: Formulate programs and initiatives for civic engagement in policymaking on AI
recommendations.text: Formulate programs and initiatives for civic engagement in policymaking on AI The Stakeholder Team flagged a general lack of civic engagement in AI policymaking. The core argument made is that policy developments often follows a top-down approach, where expert groups, industry representatives, and government bodies lead decision-making without substantial input from the broader public or civil society groups. Although initiatives such as the Dutch AI Coalition emphasize collaboration, they are often limited to those very stakeholders, rather than including a wide range of citizen perspectives. 219 Stolwijk, C., Punter, M., Timmers, P., Rabbie, J., Regeczi, D., & Dalmolen, S. (2024). Towards a sovereign digital future – the Netherlands in Europe. TNO. 220 Agenda Digitale Open Strategische Autonomie (overheid.nl) 221 SURF and SIVON have reached agreements with Google and Microsoft based on data protection impact assessments (DPIAs) to mitigate privacy risks for pupils, students and employees. 222 Kamerstuk 32034-54 223 Kamerstuk 26643-1231 75

recommendations.title: Without mechanisms to make these processes more inclusive and accessible, such as public consultations, educational
recommendations.text: Without mechanisms to make these processes more inclusive and accessible, such as public consultations, educational campaigns, or citizen assemblies on AI, there is a risk that AI policies will not adequately reflect the diverse concerns, values, and needs of Dutch society. This issue becomes of particular relevance in the case of AI being used for algorithmic-decision making.224 In response, the Stakeholder Team advised to formally integrate civic engagement programs and initiatives in the policy-making process around AI. Government response The Dutch government acknowledges the need to encourage social dialogue and cooperation at various levels in order to be able to respond to the fundamental challenges that AI poses. Ensuring safe and responsible development, use, and integration of AI, as well as maximizing the opportunities that AI offers, requires a coordinated effort from all levels of government, the private sector, technical community, academia and civil society. Together with local governments and implementation organizations, the Netherlands is exploring ways in which AI can support in making communication with citizens clearer and more inclusive. The vision on generative AI has been developed in close collaboration with all levels of government (including organisations responsible for implementing policies), businesses from several domains and sectors, academia and civil society. This cooperation remains essential in the future as well. This means actively involving several actors such as civilians, policy-makers from all levels of government, employers, businesses, entrepreneurs, scientists, employees and educators. It is essential that various actors have a voice in shaping the future where generative AI plays a role. The Dutch AI Coalition played a crucial role in fostering social dialogue, for example through the AI-Parade. This was an initiative where 35 libraries were visited across the Netherlands, where citizens could engage in debates, workshop

recommendations.title: Additionally, the Dutch government aims to raise awareness about AI. For example, through the program Digitaal
recommendations.text: Additionally, the Dutch government aims to raise awareness about AI. For example, through the program Digitaal Burgerschap (Digital Citizenship) of the Dutch Royal Library, libraries offer events and educational opportunities for citizens to learn about topics such as AI.225 Likewise, the Dutch government launched an educational campaign about digitalisation including on AI.226 The campaign was a collaboration between the government and DPG-media in which 400.000 citizens were reached. The DIGCOM monitor of the University of Amsterdam will measure, among other things, the knowledge and skills on

recommendations.text: AI of citizens on behalf of the Dutch government. Through this monitor the Dutch government aims to keep track of the current state of digital competences in the Netherlands. Alongside this monitor the Dutch government keeps track 224 Veenstra, A.-F., Timan, T., Bodea, G., Chideock, C. E., Georgieva, I. N., Lazo, C. B., & Theelen, M. A. H. (2021). TNO. https://publications.tno.nl/publication/34638227/KTvx9Y/veenstra-2021-ai.pdf 225 See Digitaal burgerschap. 226 Publicatie bewaargids 'Bewust online' | Publicatie | Rijksoverheid.nl. 76 of research and monitors that measure public sentiment and knowledge on AI, for example of the CBS227 and the

recommendations.title: Several government bodies such as the municipality of Amsterdam, initiated initiatives to engage civil society. For
recommendations.text: Several government bodies such as the municipality of Amsterdam, initiated initiatives to engage civil society. For instance, to engage discussions amongst actors and collect feedback, the Dutch government organised dialogue sessions on AI systems-use in the public sector with civil society and public sector officials. In 2023, together with civic organizations, the Ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations also organized ethical dialogues amongst several actors from Dutch society on specific use-cases of generative AI, reflecting on both its opportunities and risks for society. At the end of 2023, the Rathenau Institute has published a report with an overview of opportunities, risks and ways to deal with generative AI, which it has presented to parliament.229

recommendations.title: Build on the government-wide vision on generative AI of the Netherlands and define best-practices
recommendations.text: Build on the government-wide vision on generative AI of the Netherlands and define best-practices related to sustainability in AI development and use

recommendations.title: Even before the sudden surge of interest in generative AI, scientists had already flagged the considerable carbon
recommendations.text: Even before the sudden surge of interest in generative AI, scientists had already flagged the considerable carbon footprint of AI. It is important to acknowledge that AI is destined to play a dual role. On the one hand, it can help to reduce the effects of the climate crisis – from optimising our energy grid to developing low-emission infrastructures.

recommendations.title: Yet, on the other hand, the carbon footprint of training AI models is considerable.231 Today, the “environmental impacts
recommendations.text: Yet, on the other hand, the carbon footprint of training AI models is considerable.231 Today, the “environmental impacts are expected to escalate considerably, with the global AI energy demand projected to exponentially increase to at least 10 times the current level and exceed the annual electricity consumption of a country like Belgium by 2026”.232 In addition to the high degree of carbon emissions and electricity use, AI is also associated with substantial water consumption, ‘both directly for onsite server cooling and indirectly for offsite electricity generation’.233 In response, the Netherlands’ Stakeholder Team have recommended to define best-practices related to sustainability and environmental considerations in the development and use of AI (ideally, beyond the requirements stipulated in the AI Act). One basis to do so, would be to leverage and build on the government wide vision on generative AI (2024) where measures to reduce negative environmental impacts are advocated for. The vision advocates to focus on the integration of energy-efficient training processes and delivery, with priority given to the use of renewable energy sources. 227 Centraal Bureau voor de Statistiek | CBS 228 AlgoSoc AI Opinion Monitor 229 https://www.rathenau.nl/nl/digitalisering/generatieve-ai 230 Overheid.nl | Consultatie Wet versterking waarborgfunctie Awb 231 See Dhar, P. (2020). The carbon impact of artificial intelligence. Nature Machine Intelligence, 2(8), 423–425. https://doi.org/10.1038/s42256-020-0219-9; and Strubell, E., Ganesh, A., & McCallum, A. (2020). Energy and Policy Considerations for Modern Deep Learning Research. Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence, 34, Article 09. https://doi.org/10.1609/aaai.v34i09.7123 232 Ren, S., & Wierman, A. (2024, July 15). The Uneven Distribution of AI’s Environmental Impacts. Harvard Business Review. The Uneven

recommendations.text: Distribution of AI’s Environmental Impacts 233 Ibid. 77 It is also relevant to acknowledge the uneven distribution of AI’s environmental impacts. In its Recommendation on the

recommendations.title: Ethics of Artificial Intelligence (UNESCO, 2021), UNESCO has advised against the use of AI if it may lead to
recommendations.text: Ethics of Artificial Intelligence (UNESCO, 2021), UNESCO has advised against the use of AI if it may lead to disproportionally negative impacts on the environment.234 Therefore, it was advised by the Netherlands’ Stakeholder

recommendations.title: Team to make conscious evaluations should further investments be made into, for example, data centres or high-
recommendations.text: Team to make conscious evaluations should further investments be made into, for example, data centres or high- performance computers. Government response The Dutch government pays special attention to the impact of AI on sustainability and climate. The government recognises that (generative) AI can contribute to solving climate challenges, but so far it has only led to an increase in the ecological footprint. Therefore, the Netherlands believes it is essential to make these technologies more sustainable through more energy-efficient methods and promoting responsible and sustainable development and use. For the

recommendations.title: Dutch government, sustainability is a key principle in the deployment of AI, meaning that this technology will not be
recommendations.text: Dutch government, sustainability is a key principle in the deployment of AI, meaning that this technology will not be used if it causes significant harm to people and the planet. In 2024, Utrecht University was asked to conduct a study concerning the environmental impact of the use of generative AI by the public sector. Results of this study are expected in the beginning of 2025.

recommendations.title: More in general, the Dutch government is also committed to a sustainable digital infrastructure and the sustainability
recommendations.text: More in general, the Dutch government is also committed to a sustainable digital infrastructure and the sustainability of other sectors through digitalisation. For this purpose, an Action Plan for Sustainable Digitalisation was drawn up in

recommendations.title: June 2024.235 The action plan contains 44 actions that relate to the sustainability of the digital infrastructure itself and
recommendations.text: June 2024.235 The action plan contains 44 actions that relate to the sustainability of the digital infrastructure itself and the opportunities that digitalisation offers for sustainability in other sectors. The Dutch digitalisation sector itself has been taking important steps towards sustainability for some time now, as described in the State of the Digital

recommendations.title: Infrastructure.236 The Dutch government is working with sustainable frontrunners in the “National Coalition for
recommendations.text: Infrastructure.236 The Dutch government is working with sustainable frontrunners in the “National Coalition for Sustainable Digitalisation” to use their experiences more broadly for all entrepreneurs.

recommendations.title: Furthermore, the Energy and Sustainability working group of the NL AI Coalition will support the development of new
recommendations.text: Furthermore, the Energy and Sustainability working group of the NL AI Coalition will support the development of new AI solutions to challenges in the energy sector and around sustainability, and thus stimulate the Dutch economy.237

recommendations.title: Moreover, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has mandated Dialogic to research the energy- and water usage of AI. The
recommendations.text: Moreover, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has mandated Dialogic to research the energy- and water usage of AI. The goal is to analyse ways in which AI can be used in an energy-efficient manner. The study is expected to be published in May 2025. The Netherlands is also working with other EU Member States to exchange experiences around the dual transition of sustainability and digitalisation. A relevant fact is also that at EU level regulations in the field of circularity, recycling and reporting obligations for data centres are in place. The impact of these regulations will be monitored. Beyond the EU, the Netherlands advocates for linking sustainability more closely with digitalization in the UN World Summit on the

recommendations.title: Explore the possibilities of establishing an advisory body of experts that monitors AI developments
recommendations.text: Explore the possibilities of establishing an advisory body of experts that monitors AI developments beyond the AI Act 234 Beyond its exorbitant use of energy, AI is also associated with the consumption of large quantities of water (for server cooling and offsite electricity generation). In regions where there is already scarcity and the consequent risk for droughts are an important factor to consider (Hao, 2024). 235 Actieplan Duurzame Digitalisering | Rapport | Rijksoverheid.nl 236 Staat van de Digitale Infrastructuur | Rapport | Rijksoverheid.nl. 237 Energy and Sustainability • Nederlandse AI Coalitie (nlaic.com) 78 The dynamic nature of technological development is at odds with the nature of policy making, regulation and enforcement. In particular, this holds for AI.238 The technology needs robust governance and institutions that are apt at fulfilling the AI Act. Academics have brought this topic to attention.239 The Netherlands’ Stakeholder Team discussed the means to implement the Act by national and EU institutional bodies, and those established under the AI Act, such as the AI Office, and provided the recommendation of an additional structure – beyond those of the AI Act – by the establishment of an advisory body and expert group that continuously monitors developments in AI (including generative AI). That structure could provide guidance on technological developments as well as advise the government on the structural design of national bodies and the administrative capacities needed to enforce the AI Act. Government response

recommendations.title: Given the expected exponential growth that (generative) AI will undergo in the coming years, it is of significant
recommendations.text: Given the expected exponential growth that (generative) AI will undergo in the coming years, it is of significant importance for the Dutch government to closely monitor relevant developments. The Dutch government is, and will remain, in close contact with local governments, implementation organizations, knowledge institutions, commercial entities, public interest organizations, employers, employees, and citizens on this subject. Furthermore, the Netherlands will prioritize the implementation of the supervision and monitoring based on the AI Act.

recommendations.title: Secondly, at the request of the House of Representatives, the Dutch government also explored the establishment of
recommendations.text: Secondly, at the request of the House of Representatives, the Dutch government also explored the establishment of an AI advisory body at the highest (Dutch) political level intensively. However, the installation of an AI advisory body advising the government is subject to stringent laws on such advisory bodies, requiring careful deliberation and formal procedures. Such bodies and the way they can and cannot operate may not fulfil the need expressed by parliament.

recommendations.title: Additionally, because of the consequences for the labour market, both in terms of employment and the quality of
recommendations.text: Additionally, because of the consequences for the labour market, both in terms of employment and the quality of work, the government has asked its Social and Economic Council (Sociaal-Economische Raad, SER) to advise on the impact of AI on labour productivity, quantity, and quality of work. In other words, several institutes and advisory body are already in place when it comes to specific aspects of the implications of AI.

recommendations.title: Thirdly, AI is developing at such a rapid and disruptive pace that it is necessary to look for new ways to translate
recommendations.text: Thirdly, AI is developing at such a rapid and disruptive pace that it is necessary to look for new ways to translate knowledge and research into effective policy and to connect researchers with policymakers and the parliament. The government has worked on and continues to work on ways to address this issue through the development of a ‘Science for policy’ approach. Policies developed solely on the basis of scientific knowledge are ‘evidence-based’; ‘evidence- informed’ policy is developed when scientific knowledge is combined with practical knowledge.240 The ‘science for policy’ approach is an important tool to not only stay up-to-date on AI developments, but also to bridge the gap between policy and research in general. This is also supported by the EU platform ‘Knowledge4Policy’ which provides a high-quality research database that can be used by policymakers.241 The new European Commission has announced to strengthen the uptake of AI in research at European level, by setting up a European AI Research Council. At the level of the UN, the Netherlands plays an active role in defining the modalities of the Independent International

recommendations.title: Prioritise in the expansion of assessments and labs for responsible development of AI and in the
recommendations.text: Prioritise in the expansion of assessments and labs for responsible development of AI and in the producing of new (general) tools The Netherlands’ Stakeholder Team flagged a discrepancy between the tools and assessments for the ethical / responsible / transparent development of AI and practice. Academics are well aware of the problematics with the panoply of existing guidelines, and the gap between ethics and practice. In a recent literature study, it was flagged that ethics in the context of AI guidelines is frequently not defined and rather vague, therefore making the application challenging at best, and contested at worst.242 Guidelines often lack agreement, both in terms of what the most important principles are and what their solutions are.243 As a result, one may observe a “gulf between ethical guidelines and practical implementation, a gap between principles and practice” that may maintain the status quo and an undesired outcome “business as usual”.244

recommendations.title: When turning to industry and business organisations, the symptoms are felt. Industry representatives within the
recommendations.text: When turning to industry and business organisations, the symptoms are felt. Industry representatives within the Stakeholder Team flagged the need for more assistance in the implementation of the guidelines (and regulations). In response to these observations, it was recommended to prioritise the penetration of assessments and labs for responsible development of AI over the producing of new (general) tools. Government response

recommendations.title: Citizens and businesses must be able to trust that the government establishes appropriate frameworks and rules for
recommendations.text: Citizens and businesses must be able to trust that the government establishes appropriate frameworks and rules for (generative) AI. In this regard, attention should be paid to how existing and upcoming legislation is capable of encouraging the development and use of AI in a safe and fair manner. Clear national, European (or international) frameworks can contribute to accelerating innovation. The European AI Act provides a solid foundation in this respect. In the coming years, practical tools and guidelines are expected to be published by both the national government, supervisory authorities and the European Commission. To facilitate both private companies and government bodies with practical advice concerning compliance with the AI

recommendations.title: Act, the Netherlands is in the process of establishing regulatory sandboxes. With these sandboxes, supervisory
recommendations.text: Act, the Netherlands is in the process of establishing regulatory sandboxes. With these sandboxes, supervisory authorities enter into a regulatory dialogue with participants to assist them with AI Act related questions on the development, testing or validation of (high risk) AI systems. Such measures will help increase legal certainty, thereby stimulating innovation, and increasing the development and use of responsible and safe AI. As for the public sector, in recent years, the Dutch government has provided policy aimed at the responsible development and use of algorithms and AI by government bodies, as well as fostering innovation of such technology. As mentioned in previous chapters, tools to help foster the responsible use of AI in the public sector include a fundamental rights and algorithms impact assessment for the early mapping of risks to fundamental rights in the use of algorithms and AI. To address the ‘panoply’ of guidelines and regulations, the Dutch government published an algorithm framework in 2024.245 This framework provides an overview of applicable laws and regulations, provides practical tools and measures to take to comply with laws and regulations, as well as examples and use cases.

recommendations.title: AI. In the Netherlands, municipalities where Big Tech companies are located have raised concerns over their interest
recommendations.text: AI. In the Netherlands, municipalities where Big Tech companies are located have raised concerns over their interest in the region. The sentiment is shared that data centres are located strategically next to green energy wind parks to present users and investors with a sustainable and responsible image, even though these companies might be profiting unfairly from subsidised energy. This could lead to new inequalities as municipalities do not benefit from the green energy that is generated there locally.249 In response to these developments and trends, the Stakeholder Team recommended to commit a greater amount of resources into computing power, both in terms of data centres and high-performance computers. Government response A government that wants to be in control should be a government that, within the existing legal frameworks, can experiment with safe and responsible (generative) AI to help academia, the private sector and public organisations discover where risks and opportunities lie in specific applications. recommendations.title: Strengthening the AI ecosystem is also high on the European political agenda. On 24 January 2024, the European
recommendations.text: Strengthening the AI ecosystem is also high on the European political agenda. On 24 January 2024, the European Commission launched the AI Innovation Package, which introduced the concept of an AI factory.252 The importance of investing in AI is also reflected in Mario Draghi's recently published report on the future of European competitiveness253, and the priorities of the new European Commission for the period 2024-2029.254 The Commission announced to ensure access to new, tailored supercomputing capacity for AI start-ups and industry through an “AI Factories initiative” in the first 100 days of its mandate. The European supercomputer innovation program 'European High Performance

recommendations.title: Computing Joint Undertaking' (EuroHPC JU) has organised a call for the co-financing of AI factories in Member States.
recommendations.text: Computing Joint Undertaking' (EuroHPC JU) has organised a call for the co-financing of AI factories in Member States. The Dutch government is currently exploring the options for participation, also urged by members of parliament255, while taking into consideration the effects on the landscape and energy- and water usage.256 Additionally, the regional economic and social benefit is being explored. Depending on available funding from several sources the Dutch government, together with Dutch stakeholders, intends to submit a proposal for an AI facility in the Netherlands before the third assessment deadline, which closes in early May.

recommendations.title: Digital literacy in marginalized communities remains a critical area for policy improvement, particularly in the age of
recommendations.text: Digital literacy in marginalized communities remains a critical area for policy improvement, particularly in the age of AI, where divides can exacerbate existing inequalities.257 As AI-driven technologies become increasingly embedded in education, healthcare, and employment, those lacking basic digital skills are at a greater disadvantage.258 For marginalized groups, limited access to digital infrastructure and literacy means they miss out on opportunities to leverage tools that can enhance learning, job prospects, and access to services. Without targeted policies to improve digital literacy and ensure equitable access to AI technologies, these communities risk being left further behind in a rapidly evolving digital economy. Addressing this gap is essential for ensuring that AI benefits are distributed inclusively, empowering all sectors of society and creating a stronger societal support base for the digital economy. The Netherlands’ Stakeholder Team flagged that digital literacy in the context of marginalized communities remains a policy area for improvement.259 In response, the stakeholders recommended to develop capacities to design policy that addresses digital literacy throughout all layers of society. To do so, civic engagement and the participation of civil society in policy making was proposed as valuable method to follow. 250 Kabinet presenteert visie op generatieve AI | Nieuwsbericht | Rijksoverheid.nl 251 Regeerprogramma (overheid.nl), page 122. 252 Commission launches AI innovation package (europa.eu) 253 EU competitiveness: Looking ahead - European Commission (europa.eu) 254 e6cd4328-673c-4e7a-8683-f63ffb2cf648_en (europa.eu) 255 Motie van het lid Kathmann (16/01/2025). 256 Kamerbrief verkenning mogelijkheden AI-faciliteit | Kamerstuk | Rijksoverheid.nl; Motie van het lid Kathmann (16/01/2025); Motie van het lid Vermeer (16/01/2025). 257 This was particularly recognized in the context of generative AI (Hendawy, 2024). 258 Gonzales, S. (2024, August 6).

recommendations.title: Technological developments, such as the development of generative AI, increase the production and dissemination of
recommendations.text: Technological developments, such as the development of generative AI, increase the production and dissemination of disinformation. Distinguishing between reliable, objective and factual news and disinformation is becoming increasingly confusing. In addition, AI technology can facilitate microtargeting, posing risks both to privacy and personal autonomy. This necessitates further efforts to increase media literacy among various target groups in order to prevent less digitally adept people from falling behind as well as protecting them from potentially negative effects of AI. In the Netherlands, the Dutch Network on Media Literacy helps foster media literacy among Dutch society, focussing on both resilience against risks and the opportunities AI offers. In the entire educational system, skills such as critical and structured thinking are becoming increasingly necessary. In this context, the reform of the curriculum for primary and secondary education is important. The new core educational objective on digital literacy as recently launched for primary and secondary education, considers four domains: 1) practical ICT skills, 2) media literacy, 3) digital information skills, 4) computational thinking. Students will acquire knowledge about digital technology, learn how to collaborate with them in a critical and (self)conscious manner, and assess the opportunities and risks involved in using them, which is all very relevant for AI. The AI Act lists a number of factors that weigh in when promoting AI literacy, but these need further fleshing out to provide sufficient guidance. In the context, the Dutch privacy authority has published a short guide to promote AI literacy within organizations that develop AI-systems.260 The Dutch government has an active policy to address disinformation and fake news, taking into account new possibilities based on AI. In its letter of 17 June 2024 it has reported its progress to Dutch parliament.261 Promoting media literacy of Dutch citizens

Standards play an important role in this. Supervisors have a role to support companies, large and small, preventively, and proactively in the practical application of the complex legal rules and thus contribute to limiting the high regulatory burden”.263 It is worthwhile to note that the European Union has taken action on this. Notably, by setting up procurement grants to develop “harmonised frameworks, tools and infrastructure at European level to support compliance with the AI Act that have been tested in practice by under-resourced SMEs and public authorities”.264 The Netherlands can play an important role here and one suggested approach is to assess how rules and regulations interplay

recommendations.title: December 2024, the Netherlands has addressed the theme of better regulation in the digital domain and proposed
recommendations.text: December 2024, the Netherlands has addressed the theme of better regulation in the digital domain and proposed to particularly discuss the burden for SMEs in next Council meetings. The Netherlands has also welcomed the announcement by the European Commission to prioritise an assessment that would identify whether the digital acquis – all agreed EU regulation in the digital domain - reflect the needs of SMEs. The Dutch government has called upon the European Commission to strictly enforce the evaluation clauses of the legislation under the digital rulebook.265 Additionally, the Dutch government has spoken out in favour of a review of the entire digital rulebook as a whole when all laws have been implemented. Through such a review, the effectiveness and interplay of the legislation can be mapped and improved. The Dutch government is working on establishing regulatory sandboxes for the AI Act. In 2024, a pilot was conducted to gather information on the practical aspects of operating a sandbox and to receive input from stakeholders. An important aspect of the AI Act sandbox is ‘regulatory learning’. According to this principle, the insights and learned lessons from regulatory sandboxes on the application of the AI Act should be shared broadly within the AI-ecosystem and with policy makers. An important point of attention for the Dutch government in the further implementation is how regulatory sandboxes can contribute to harmonised application of the AI Act.

recommendations.title: Develop a coherent and unified strategy to retain and attract talent around AI
recommendations.text: Develop a coherent and unified strategy to retain and attract talent around AI For the Netherlands, attracting AI talent from abroad is particularly important due to the country's ambitions. While it boasts a strong educational system, the Stakeholder Team has observed that the demand for specialized AI skills exceeds the supply of homegrown talent. To maintain its competitive edge in the global AI race, the Netherlands needs to attract top-tier international talent to bridge these gaps. 263 VNO-NCW & MKB-Nederland. (2024, October 1). recommendations.title: Developing and retaining talent in the Netherlands is also a matter of ensuring diversity and inclusion, which is not yet
recommendations.text: Developing and retaining talent in the Netherlands is also a matter of ensuring diversity and inclusion, which is not yet fully integrated into the country's AI sector. Although the Netherlands is known for its open, multicultural society, there is still work to be done in creating diverse teams that represent a variety of backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences. This diversity is essential for addressing biases in AI models and ensuring that the technology benefits all sectors of society266. Furthermore, building inclusive talent pipelines that encourage participation from women, minorities, and underrepresented groups will be critical to both the ethical and practical development of AI technologies. The Dutch government and institutions have acknowledged this challenge and yet, the Stakeholder Team has advised for more deliberate efforts to integrate these diverse perspectives into AI development. To attract and nurture talent, the Netherlands could enhance its international collaborations to foster a more orchestrated effort in knowledge exchange. Dutch universities and research institutions already have strong ties to

recommendations.title: European and global partners267, but there is room for more structured and frequent exchanges of expertise.
recommendations.text: European and global partners267, but there is room for more structured and frequent exchanges of expertise. Strengthening collaborations with other hubs internationally and other parts of Europe can help the Netherlands remain at the forefront of AI advancements. Such exchanges—whether through academic partnerships, joint research initiatives, or cross-border innovation projects—will allow practitioners to continuously update their skills, learn from global best practices, and contribute to a shared global vision for AI development. In reflection to these observations, it was recommended that the Netherlands develop a coherent and unified strategy to retain and attract talent around AI. This ought to include plans on attracting foreign talent (both technical and non- technical), plans on diversity and inclusion, as well as knowledge exchanges. Government response The Dutch government is committed to developing and retaining AI talent, so that we can develop (generative) AI that meets European norms and values. This is also of added value for the digital open strategic autonomy of Europe.

recommendations.title: Through the Action Plan Green and Digital Jobs, the government is tackling the issue of labour market shortages in
recommendations.text: Through the Action Plan Green and Digital Jobs, the government is tackling the issue of labour market shortages in the climate and digital transition.268 The AINed program is an example of an initiative focused at the implementation of digital technology by businesses. In 2024, this cabinet also announced the National Strengthening Plan for Microchip-talent. This plan aims to train additional technical talent for the microchip industry as soon as possible. This is badly needed and urgent: up to and including 2030, the expectation is that there is a growth in the talent need of 38,000 additional technically trained people. To improve the location climate for the microchip industry in the Netherlands, there is more than 2 billion available from the central government. Specifically for the talent task, up to and including 2030, € 450 million is incidentally available and from 2031 € 80 million per year is structurally reserved.269 The Dutch government is also exploring the (necessary) investments in large-scale scientific and technological infrastructure (including supercomputers and computational power) at the national and EU level to be competitive in the field of LLMs (Large Language Models) and other forms of (generative) AI, which will attract and retain talent. 266 Georgieva, I., Lazo, C., Timan, T., & van Veenstra, A.
